hints_html:
Remember that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus says that

\[\begin{aligned} \frac{d}{dx}\int_a^x f(t) dt = f(x).\end{aligned}\]

Recall that

: \int_a^b f(t)dt = -\int_b^a f(t)dt
hints_raw:
Remember that the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus says that

:<math> \frac{d}{dx}\int_a^x f(t) dt = f(x) </math>.
Recall that

:<math> \int_a^b f(t)dt = -\int_b^a f(t)dt
question: 1 (b)
sols_html:
Using hint 2 provided, we may immediatley rewrite \(f(t)\) as

\[\begin{aligned} f(t)=-\int_2^{t^4} \sqrt{1+x^3}dx\end{aligned}\]

We would like to use hint 1, but this only works if the upper limit of integration is \(t\), which in this case is not true. So define for the time being

\[\begin{aligned} g(u) = -\int_2^u \sqrt{1 + x^3}dx.\end{aligned}\]

From hint 1, we see immediately that \(g'(u) = -\sqrt{1 + u^3}\). We also see that \(f(t) = g(t^4)\). Using the chain rule we can then compute that

\[\begin{aligned} f'(t) = g'(t^4) \frac{du}{dt} = -\sqrt{1 + (t^{4})^3}(4t^3) = -4t^3\sqrt{1 + t^{12}}.\end{aligned}\]
sols_raw:
Using hint 2 provided, we may immediatley rewrite <math>f(t)</math> as

:<math>f(t)=-\int_2^{t^4} \sqrt{1+x^3}dx</math>

We would like to use hint 1, but this only works if the upper limit of integration is <math>t</math>, which in this case is not true. So define for the time being

:<math> g(u) = -\int_2^u \sqrt{1 + x^3}dx </math>.

From hint 1, we see immediately that <math> g'(u) = -\sqrt{1 + u^3}</math>. We also see that <math> f(t) = g(t^4)</math>. Using the chain rule we can then compute that

:<math>f'(t) = g'(t^4) \frac{du}{dt} = -\sqrt{1 + (t^{4})^3}(4t^3) = -4t^3\sqrt{1 + t^{12}}</math>.
statement_html:
For this question, the exam asks to put your answer in the box provided but also to show your work. This question is worth 3 marks. Full marks is given for correct answers placed in the box and at most 1 mark is given for an incorrect answer. You are required to simplify your answers as much as possible.

Find the derivative \(\displaystyle f'(t)\), if

\(f(t) = \int_{t^4}^2 \sqrt{1+x^3} dx\)
